Organization for Migration |accessdate=20 February 2017 |ref=harv |language=en |date=11 February 2015}}</ref> Furthermore, none of the six states have signed the most important conventions on the protection of the rights of migrant workers, namely the [[Migration for Employment Convention (Revised), 1949|1949 Migration for Employment Convention]],<ref>{{cite web |author1=International Labour Organization |title=Ratifications of C097 - Migration for Employment Convention (Revised), 1949 (No. 97) |url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=NORMLEXPUB:11300:0::NO::P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312242 |website=www.ilo.org |accessdate=20 February 2017 |ref=harv |language=en}}</ref> the [[Migrant Workers (Supplementary Provisions) Convention, 1975|1975 Migrant Workers Convention (Supplementary Provisions)]],<ref>{{cite web |author1=International Labour Organization |title=Ratifications of C143 - Migrant Workers (Supplementary Provisions) Convention, 1975 (No. 143) |url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312288 |website=www.ilo.org |accessdate=20 February 2017 |ref=harv |language=en}}</ref> and the 1990 [[International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of Their Families]].<ref>{{cite web |author1=United Nations Human Rights: Office of the High Commissioner |title=Status of Ratification: International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of their Families |url=http://indicators.ohchr.org/ |website=indicators.ohchr.org |accessdate=20 February 2017 |ref=harv |language=en}}</ref> Of the so-called eight fundamental conventions of the International Labour Organization, Bahrain has ratified five conventions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11200:0::NO:11200:P11200_COUNTRY_ID:103396|title=Ratifications of ILO conventions: Ratifications for Bahrain|author=|date=|website=www.ilo.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref>, Kuwait has ratified seven conventions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11200:0::NO:11200:P11200_COUNTRY_ID:103423|title=Ratifications of ILO conventions: Ratifications for Kuwait|author=|date=|website=www.ilo.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref> , Oman has ratified four conventions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11200:0::NO:11200:P11200_COUNTRY_ID:103441|title=Ratifications of ILO conventions: Ratifications for Oman|author=|date=|website=www.ilo.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref> , Qatar has ratified five conventions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11200:0::NO:11200:P11200_COUNTRY_ID:103429|title=Ratifications of ILO conventions: Ratifications for Qatar|author=|date=|website=www.ilo.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref>, Saudi Arabia has ratified six conventions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11200:0::NO:11200:P11200_COUNTRY_ID:103208|title=Ratifications of ILO conventions: Ratifications for Saudi Arabia|author=|date=|website=www.ilo.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref> and the UAE have also ratified six conventions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11200:0::NO:11200:P11200_COUNTRY_ID:103495|title=Ratifications of ILO conventions: Ratifications for United Arab Emirates|author=|date=|website=www.ilo.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref>. All have ratified the 1930 [[Forced Labour Convention]],<ref>{{cite web |author1=International Labour Organization |title=Ratifications of C029 - Forced Labour Convention, 1930 (No. 29) |url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312174 |website=www.ilo.org |accessdate=20 February 2017 |ref=harv |language=en}}</ref> and the 1957 [[Abolition of Forced Labour Convention]].<ref>{{cite web |author1=International Labour Organization |title=Ratifications of C105 - Abolition of Forced Labour Convention, 1957 (No. 105) |url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312250 |website=www.ilo.org |accessdate=20 February 2017 |ref=harv |language=en |quote=}}</ref>
===National legal regimes===
====Kafala system==== An important concept which regulates migrant labor in the GCC countries is the [[kafala system]], a sponsorship system which provides the legal basis for both residency and employment of migrant workers in the GCC countries.<ref name = "Roper">Roper & Barria 2014a, p. 34</ref><ref name="Malaeb2015" >{{cite journal |last1=Malaeb |first1=Hanan N. |title=The "Kafala" System and Human Rights: Time for Decision |journal=Arab Law Quarterly |date=21 October 2015 |volume=29 |issue=4 |pages=307–342 |doi=10.1163/15730255-12341307 |url=https://heinonline.org/hol-cgi-bin/get_pdf.cgi?handle=hein.journals/arablq29&section=21 |accessdate=24 November 2018 |ref=harv |language=en |issn=1573-0255}}, pp. 309-310.</ref> It relies on a citizen or organization, the kafeel (sponsor) within one of the GCC countries employing migrant workers, which is the only manner in which the migrant worker can receive an entry visa, residence permit and work permit.<ref name = "Roper"/><ref name="Malaeb2015" /> Furthermore, under the kafala system, the sponsor takes on both legal and economic responsibility for the migrant worker.<ref name = "Roper"/><ref name="Malaeb2015" /> This system binds the migrant worker to the employer, as the migrant is allowed only to work for the kafeel and only for the duration of the contract.<ref name = "Roper"/><ref name="Malaeb2015" /> The kafala system remains an important part of the laws regulating migrant workers in all of the Gulf states, even though many of these laws have been amended in the Gulf states in the past 15 years.
====National laws and regulations==== Since its creation in 2006 the Bahraini Labour Market Regulation Authority (LMRA) is tasked, not only with the regulation of, inter alia, employment transfers, recruitment agencies and work visas, but also with informing migrant workers of their rights and obligations.<ref name = "Steps">{{cite web |title=Saudi Arabia: Steps Toward Migrant Workers' Rights |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/11/15/saudi-arabia-steps-toward-migrant-workers-rights |publisher=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=27 November 2018 |ref=harv |date=15 November 2015}}</ref><ref name="HRW Qatar2015">{{cite web |title=Qatar: New Reforms Won’t Protect Migrant Workers |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/11/08/qatar-new-reforms-wont-protect-migrant-workers |website=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=1 December 2018 |ref=harv |date=8 November 2015}}</ref><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015">{{cite web |title=Kuwait: New Law a Breakthrough for Domestic Workers |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/06/30/kuwait-new-law-breakthrough-domestic-workers |website=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=1 December 2018 |ref=harv |date=30 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="HRW Bahrain">{{cite web |title=For a Better Life: Migrant Worker Abuse in Bahrain and the Government Reform Agenda |url=https://www.hrw.org/report/2012/09/30/better-life/migrant-worker-abuse-bahrain-and-government-reform-agenda |website=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=1 December 2018 |ref=harv |date=30 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010">{{cite web |title=Kuwait: Government Pledges to End Sponsorship System |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2010/09/28/kuwait-government-pledges-end-sponsorship-system |website=Human Rights Watch |accessdate=1 December 2018 |ref=harv |date=28 September 2010}}</ref> Furthermore, the existing legal regime regarding labor is applicable to both national and foreign workers.<ref name = "Steps"/><ref name="HRW Qatar2015"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015"/><ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010"/>The protections offered by Bahrain's criminal law to workers applies to migrant workers as well.<ref name = "Steps"/><ref name="HRW Qatar2015"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015"/><ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010"/>
In 2009, Bahrain announced that it would end the kafala system, citing human rights concerns linked to both human trafficking and sexual slavery.<ref>Roper & Barria 2014a, p. 32</ref> The Labour Market Regulatory Law was amended, making the LMRA the official sponsor of migrant workers and, most importantly, allowing migrant workers to leave their employer without the latter's consent.<ref name="BahrainScrapped">{{cite web |title=Three Months After the Sponsorship System in Bahrain was “Scrapped”, What Really Changed? |url=https://www.migrant-rights.org/2009/11/three-months-after-the-sponsorship-system-in-bahrain-was-scrapped-what-really-changed/ |website=Migrant-Rights.org |accessdate=1 December 2018 |ref=harv |date=11 November 2009}}</ref> <ref name="KhanHarroff-Tavel2011"> {{cite journal |last1=Khan |first1=Azfar |last2=Harroff-Tavel |first2=Hélène |title=Reforming the Kafala: Challenges and Opportunities in Moving Forward |journal=Asian and Pacific Migration Journal |date=September 2011 |volume=20 |issue=3–4 |pages=293–313 |doi=10.1177/011719681102000303 |url=http://www.academia.edu/download/37129775/2_Azfar_Khan_Helene_Harroff-Tavel.pdf |accessdate=17 November 2018 |ref=harv |language=en |issn=0117-1968}}, p. 300</ref> In December 2016, the Bahraini government announced the official and total abolition of the sponsorship system once more.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bahrain abolishes sponsorship system for foreign workers |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/business/economy/2016/12/19/Bahrain-abolishes-sponsorship-system-for-foreign-workers.html |accessdate=1 December 2018 |work=english.alarabiya.net |publisher=Al Arabiya English |date=19 December 2016 |ref=harv |language=en}}</ref><ref name= "Review">{{cite web |title=Migration in the Gulf: 2016 in Review |url=https://www.migrant-rights.org/2017/01/migration-in-the-gulf-2016-in-review/ |website=Migrant-Rights.org |accessdate=1 December 2018 |ref=harv |date=1 January 2017}}</ref>
Other legislative initiatives to protect labor rights in Bahrain include a 2012 private sector labor law, focusing inter alia on the number of sick days, annual leave, compensation for unfair dismissals, fines for labor law violations and the streamlining of labor disputes.<ref name="HRW Bahrain" /><ref name="Zahra2015" >{{cite journal |last1=Zahra |first1=M. |title=Bahrain's Legal Framework of Migration |journal=Gulf Labour Markets and Migration |date=2015|volume=1 |issue=2015 |pages= |url= |accessdate= |ref=harv}}</ref> A 2008 human trafficking law was presented by the Bahraini government as covering many common labor law violations, for example the withholding of wages.<ref name = "Steps"/><ref name="HRW Qatar2015"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015"/><ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010"/> Furthermore, in late 2016 Bahrain was considering to allow the issuance of flexible work permits for undocumented workers, providing them with the ability to work for more than one employer even without legal visa.<ref name="FlexibleWork Bahrain2016" >{{cite web |title=Flexible Work Permit for Undocumented Workers: Bahrain |url=https://www.migrant-rights.org/2016/10/flexible-work-permit-for-undocumented-workers-bahrain/ |website=Migrant-Rights.org |accessdate=1 December 2018 |ref=harv |date=17 October 2016}}</ref>
The main legal source for the kafala system in Kuwait is the 1959 Aliens’ Residence Law and its implementing regulations. This law not only provided that all foreign workers should have a local sponsor, but also that the responsibility of monitoring the foreign workers lies with the sponsor.<ref name="HRW Oman2016">Human Rights Watch, “Abuse and Exploitation of Migrant Domestic Workers in Oman”, 13 July 2016, ''available [https://www.hrw.org/report/2016/07/13/i-was-sold/abuse-and-exploitation-migrant-domestic-workers-oman here]''</ref><ref name="HRW2016">Human Rights Watch, "Migrant Domestic Workers: Overworked and Underprotected", 15 June 2016, ''available [https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/06/15/migrant-domestic-workers-overworked-and-underprotected here]''</ref><ref name="HRW KSA2010">Human Rights Watch, "Saudi Arabia: Domestic Worker Brutalised", 2 September 2010, ''available [https://www.hrw.org/news/2010/09/02/saudi-arabia-domestic-worker-brutalized here]''</ref><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010b">Human Rights Watch, “Kuwait: For Abused Domestic Workers, Nowhere to Turn”, 6 October 2010, ''available [https://www.hrw.org/news/2010/10/06/kuwait-abused-domestic-workers-nowhere-turn here]''</ref><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015b">Human Rights Watch, “Walls at Every Turn: Abuse of Migrant Domestic Workers through Kuwait’s Sponsorship System”, 6 October 2010, ''available [https://www.hrw.org/report/2010/10/06/walls-every-turn/abuse-migrant-domestic-workers-through-kuwaits-sponsorship-system here]''</ref> Furthermore, migrant workers were also covered the 1964 Law concerning Labour in the Private Sector,<ref>Shah 2011, p. 353</ref> the sector in which most foreign workers are active. The legal system regulating foreign workers has been changing since the early 2000s. For example, in 2007, the Kuwaiti Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs implemented a decree which prohibited employers from taking their employees’ passports.<ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="HRW2016" /><ref name="HRW KSA2010" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010b" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015b" /> In 2009, another decree was issued, which allowed migrant workers to change employers without the employer's consent.<ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="HRW2016" /><ref name="HRW KSA2010" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010b" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015b" /> However, this would only be a possibility after the initial employment contract was completed, or after the worker had been employed for three consecutive years.<ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="HRW2016" /><ref name="HRW KSA2010" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010b" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015b" />
In 2010, the Kuwaiti Minister of Social Affairs and Labor announced that it would abolish the kafala system, requesting the assistance of the ILO on policy issues related to migrant workers.<ref name="KhanHarroff-Tavel2011"/> New labor laws were implemented in 2010<ref>Shah 2011, p. 341</ref><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015b" /> One major change was the creation of an agency, the Public Authority for Manpower (PAM), which has the sole responsibility for the importation and employment of foreign workers.<ref name = "Shah">Shah 2011, p. 354</ref> The agency also works to prevent the practice of visa trading, in which sponsors or local agencies would charge potential migrant workers large sums for work visas in exchange for employment, without providing the migrant with actual employment.<ref name = "Shah"/> Additionally, the new labor laws placed limits on daily working hours, while also providing for end-of-service payments, paid maternity leave and access to labor dispute settlement mechanisms.<ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="HRW2016" /><ref name="HRW KSA2010" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010b" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015b" /> The 2010 laws also incorporated the 2009 ministerial decree regarding the possibility to change employers into actual law, while maintaining the requirements of the 2009 decree.<ref name="HRW Kuwait2010" /> However, the new laws did not set a minimum wage requirements, did not allow for the creation of labor unions and did not cover domestic workers.<ref>Migrant-Rights.org, “Kuwait Doesn’t Allow Migrants to Form Labor Unions”, 31 March 2010, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2010/03/kuwait-forbids-migrants-from-forming-labor-unions/ here]</ref>
In 2015, the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs of Kuwait approved a standardized labor contract for foreign workers in the private sector, issued by the PAM, which specifies end-of-contract compensation, holidays and leaves.<ref name = "Unified"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2017">Human Rights Watch, “Kuwait: Events of 2016”, 17 January 2017, available [https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2017/country-chapters/kuwait#b94615 here]</ref> The standardized contract allows for additional articles to be added as long as these extra articles comply with Kuwait's labor laws.<ref name = "Unified">Migrant-Rights.org, “UAE Announces Reforms to Labor Rules: Kuwait and Qatar Move Forward on Unified Contracts”, 11 October 2016, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2015/10/uae-announces-reforms-to-labor-rules-kuwait-and-qatar-more-forward-on-unified-contracts/ here]</ref> Furthermore, the government distributed copies of this standardized contract among embassies for translation.<ref name = "Unified"/> In the same year, the government adopted new labor laws which extended labor rights to domestic workers and in 2016 the government set a minimum wage for domestic work.<ref>Migrant-Rights.org, “Another Look at Kuwait’s New Laws for Domestic Workers”, 10 August 2015, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2015/08/another-look-at-kuwaits-new-laws-for-domestic-workers/ here]</ref><ref> Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain, “Kuwait First in GCC to Implement Minimum Wage for Domestic Workers”, 16 July 2016, available [http://www.adhrb.org/2016/07/kuwait-implements-minimum-wage-domestic-workers/ here]</ref>
In '''Oman''', the kafala system is regulated by the foreign residency law and accompanying laws, while the system is enforced by the Ministry of Manpower and the Royal Oman Police.<ref name="HRW Kuwait2017" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Dreams" /><ref name="HRW UAE2014">Human Rights Watch, "United Arab Emirates: Trapped, Exploited, Abused", 22 October 2014, ''available [https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/10/22/united-arab-emirates-trapped-exploited-abused here].''</ref> According to Oman's 2003 Labour Law, an employer needs a permit issued by the Ministry of Manpower in order to import foreign workers.<ref>Sultanate of Oman, Ministry of Manpower, ''Labour Law, issued by Royal Decree No. 35/2003'', art. 18, available [https://www.manpower.gov.om/Portal/Englishpdf/Service/toc_en.pdf here]</ref> Furthermore, migrant workers are prohibited from working for another employer.<ref>Sultanate of Oman, Ministry of Manpower, ''Labour Law, issued by Royal Decree No. 35/2003'', art. 18(bis), available [https://www.manpower.gov.om/Portal/Englishpdf/Service/toc_en.pdf here]</ref> The Labour Law places responsibility for the migrant worker on the employer.<ref name="Mekheil2016" >Mekheil, M., “Oman Neglects the Rights of Migrant Domestic Workers”, ''Human Rights Brief'', 14 November 2016, available [http://hrbrief.org/2016/11/oman-neglects-rights-migrant-domestic-workers/ here]</ref><ref> Sultanate of Oman, Ministry of Manpower, ''Labour Law, issued by Royal Decree No. 35/2003'', art. 18(bis), available [https://www.manpower.gov.om/Portal/Englishpdf/Service/toc_en.pdf here]</ref> The 2003 Law also sets conditions for the labor contract, as well as the rights and obligations of both employers and migrant workers, including the provision of medical facilities, suitable means of transport and a minimum wage by the Council of Ministers.<ref>Sultanate of Oman, Ministry of Manpower, ''Labour Law, issued by Royal Decree No. 35/2003'', art. 23, 33-34, 50, available [https://www.manpower.gov.om/Portal/Englishpdf/Service/toc_en.pdf here]</ref> In addition, if a migrant worker wishes to change employers, the employee needs to receive a No Objection Certificate from the employer.<ref name= "Review" />
In 2011, Oman reportedly informed the United Nations Human Rights Council that alternatives to the kafala system were being considered.<ref name = "Trapped">Human Rights Watch, “Oman: Domestic Workers Trafficked, Trapped”, 13 July 2016, available [https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/07/13/oman-domestic-workers-trafficked-trapped here]</ref> However, the sponsorship system still remains in place today.<ref name = "Trapped"/> Legislative amendments to the Omani labor laws were under consideration in late 2016.<ref>Zawya, “Omanisation: New labour law under process”, 7 December 2016, available [http://www.zawya.com/mena/en/story/Omanisation_New_labour_law_under_process-ZAWYA20161208025850/ here]</ref><ref name= "Review" />The Ministry of Manpower also announced in 2016 the abolition of the obligatory No Objection Certificate.<ref name= "Review" /><ref> Gulf Business, “Oman to scrap no objection certificate for workers switching jobs”, 11 October 2016, available [http://gulfbusiness.com/oman-scrap-no-objection-certificate-for-workers-switching-jobs/ here]</ref>
In '''Qatar''' before 2009, the entry, residence and employment of foreigners was regulated by different consecutive laws, dating back to 1963.<ref name = "Jaffir">Jaffir, A., “Sponsorship Law”, Al Tamimi & Company Law Update 2009:219, available [http://altamimi.newsweaver.ie/Newsletter/10o0jspqam5 here]</ref> In 2009 these laws were merged into one so-called “sponsorship law”, the Law No. 4 Regulating the Entry, Exit, Residence & Sponsorship of Foreigners.<ref name = "Jaffir"/> Both the 2009 Sponsorship Law and the laws that preceded the Sponsorship Law were codifications of the kafala system. The 2009 law provided that migrant workers could only receive residence permits without sponsorship in very limited circumstances, that migrant workers are only allowed to work for the employer which sponsored them and that sponsorships can only be transferred by the Minister of Interior in case of labor disputes or when abuse of the employee could be proven.<ref name = "Jaffir"/> The law additionally required employers to provide employees with exit permits if they wished to leave Qatar either temporarily or permanently, but also forced employers to return passports to employees once the residency procedure is completed.<ref name = "Jaffir"/>
In May 2014, Qatar announced its intentions to reform the labor laws and to abolish the kafala system.<ref name="HRW Qatar2015" /><ref> Bishara, M., “Qatar 2022: New labor laws 'fails to prevent exploitation’ says Amnesty”, CNN, 13 December 2016, available [http://edition.cnn.com/2016/12/12/football/qatar-world-cup-2022-migrant-rights-crisis-amnesty-international/ here]</ref> A new law, titled Law No. 21 on the Entry, Exit and Residency of Foreign Nationals replacing the 2009 Sponsorship Law, was adopted in 2015 and entered into force in December 2016.<ref name="HRW Qatar2015" /><ref name = "Amnesty Qatar2016">Amnesty International, “New name old system? Qatar’s new employment law and abuse of migrant workers”, 12 December 2016, available [http://www.amnestyusa.org/research/reports/new-name-old-system-qatar-s-new-employment-law-and-abuse-of-migrant-workers here]</ref> The aim of the new law was enhancing the rights and protection of migrant workers, although the law has been criticized for insufficiently enhancing migrant worker protection.<ref name="HRW Qatar2015" /><ref> Bishara, M., “Qatar 2022: New labor laws ‘fails to prevent exploitation’ says Amnesty”, CNN, 13 December 2016, available [http://edition.cnn.com/2016/12/12/football/qatar-world-cup-2022-migrant-rights-crisis-amnesty-international/ here]</ref><ref name="Amnesty Qatar2016" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /> According to Amnesty International, the new law still requires migrant workers to obtain their employer's permission to change employment or to leave Qatar.<ref name="Amnesty Qatar2016" /> Furthermore, even after completion of the labor contract, the migrant worker wishing to find employment elsewhere in Qatar will need permission from “the competent authority”, as well as from the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs, without the law specifying who is meant by the competent authority.<ref name="HRW Qatar2015" />The law also prohibits migrant workers from establishing labor unions or organizing strikes.<ref name = "HRW Qatar2017" >Human Rights Watch, “Qatar: Events of 2016”, 17 January 2017, available [https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2017/country-chapters/Qatar here]</ref> Additionally, in 2015, the Qatari government announced its plan to set up an electronic contract system, in which workers can find their labor contract which would be available in ten different languages.<ref name= "Review"/>
In '''Saudi Arabia''', the kafala system is enshrined in the 1969 Labor Law.<ref name = "Dreams">Human Rights Watch, “Bad Dreams: Exploitation and Abuse of Migrant Workers in Saudi Arabia”, 2004:16 (No. 5), pp. 19-20, available [https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/saudi0704.pdf here]</ref> The 1969 law required every migrant worker to have signed a contract with an employer, placing them directly under the responsibility of the sponsor.<ref name = "Dreams"/> The employers were required to subsequently request the Saudi government to grant work permits for these migrant workers.<ref name = "Dreams"/> Work permits were granted upon arrival of the migrant workers, but only if they could show their employment contracts signed by both themselves and the sponsor.<ref name = "Dreams"/>
The 2005 Labour Law constituted a revision of the 1969 Labor Law, but contained many of the kafala elements found in the old 1969 Labor Law. The Ministry of Labor held the responsibility for work and residence permits.<ref>Saudi Arabia, ''2006 Labour Law (Royal Decree No. M/51)'', art. 32.</ref> Migrant workers could only receive work permits after signing a contract with an employer and being under the responsibility of the employer.<ref>Saudi Arabia, ''2006 Labour Law (Royal Decree No. M/51)'', art. 33(3).</ref> Migrant workers were not allowed to work for other employers, nor were employers permitted to employ migrant workers belonging to other employers.<ref>Saudi Arabia, ''2006 Labour Law (Royal Decree No. M/51)'', art. 39(1).</ref> The labor contract had to state the duration of the employment.<ref>Saudi Arabia, ''2006 Labour Law (Royal Decree No. M/51)'', art. 37.</ref>
The 2005 Labour Law was amended in 2013, which provided Saudi police and labor authorities with the power to enforce the provisions of the Labor Law against undocumented laborers.<ref name = "Detained">Human Rights Watch, “Detained, Beaten, Deported: Saudi Abuses against Migrants during Mass Expulsions”, 10 May 2015, available [https://www.hrw.org/report/2015/05/10/detained-beaten-deported/saudi-abuses-against-migrants-during-mass-expulsions#_ftn21 here]</ref> Punishments included both detention and deportation.<ref name = "Detained"/> The 2005 Labour Law was again amended in 2015, introducing more extensive labor protections. First of all, the amendments criminalized a series of abuse labor practices.<ref name = "Steps"/> Secondly, the amendments increase paid leave and job-related injury compensation and oblige employers, when terminating a worker's contract, to provide the worker with a week's payment so other employment can be found.<ref name = "Steps"/> Thirdly, the amendments enhance the powers of inspection and enforcement of the Ministry of Labor.<ref name = "Steps"/>
Additionally, amendments included the introduction fines for labor rights violations, including the confiscations of passports, excessive working hours, dangerous working conditions, absent labor contracts, delayed salary payments and false reports of unauthorized leave.<ref name = "MigrantRightsSaudiArabia2016">Migrant-Rights.Org, “Recent Laws in Saudi Reinforce Migrant Workers’ Vulnerability”, 31 July 2016, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2016/07/recent-laws-in-saudi-reinforce-migrant-workers-vulnerability/ here]</ref><ref name="Steps" /> Fines, as well as prison sentences, were also introduced for migrant workers who stayed in Saudi Arabia beyond the length of their residency permit and for leaving without the employer's permission.<ref name = "MigrantRightsSaudiArabia2016"/><ref>Migrant-Rights.Org, “New Fines in Saudi Arabia for Employers’ Violations”, 24 January 2016, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2016/01/new-fines-in-saudi-arabia-for-employers-violations/ here]</ref>
In the '''United Arab Emirates''', the kafala system was part of the 1980 Federal Law on the Regulation of Labour Relations, which regulated the relationship between the state, the sponsor and the sponsored.<ref name = "KeaneMcGeehan2008">{{cite journal |last1=Keane |first1=David |last2=McGeehan |first2=Nicholas |title=Enforcing Migrant Workers' Rights in the United Arab Emirates |journal=International Journal on Minority and Group Rights |date=1 March 2008 |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=81–115 |doi=10.1163/138548708X272537 |url=http://eprints.mdx.ac.uk/id/eprint/4684 |accessdate=28 November 2018 |ref=harv |language=en |issn=1571-8115}}, pp. 85-86</ref>The law did not require any written contract to be drawn up between the employer and the migrant worker.<ref name = "KeaneMcGeehan2008"/> Migrant workers required the permission of their employers to change employment and the provided sponsorship could not be transferred to another employer.<ref name = "KeaneMcGeehan2008"/> The 1980 Law did regulate issues such as severance pay, repatriation pay, annual leave, standards for maximum working hours and working conditions, payment for overtime and the payment for treatment of labor-related injuries.<ref name = "KeaneMcGeehan2008"/> However, the law also prohibited labor unions and strikes.<ref name = "KeaneMcGeehan2008"/>
Labor law reforms were introduced in the UAE in 2016, which included a standardized offer letter prepared by the UAE's Ministry of Labor, a standardized work contract which must specify duration, nature of the work, place of employment, wages and remuneration.<ref name = "Changes">Migrant-Rights.Org, “Changes to UAE Labor Law”, 13 March 2016, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2016/03/new-labor-changes-in-the-uae/ here]</ref> The changes also specify working hours as 8 hours per day or 48 hours per week.<ref name = "Changes"/> However, these working hours could be higher for those working in the service industry.<ref name = "Changes"/> Furthermore, migrant workers are allowed to change employers after six months and only if their employer consents, or if employment is not provided or if a legal complaint of some sort is issued.<ref name = "Changes"/> Both parties can agree to end the employment contract after six months.<ref name = "Changes"/> According to the reforms, contracts must be made available in both Arabic, English and a third language if required.<ref name = "Changes"/> Employers who fail to provide translations are subjected to fines.<ref name = "Changes"/>
====Specific rights and protections==== With regards to the rights and protections granted to migrant workers, the following rights are granted to migrant workers by all GCC countries: * The right to end of service benefits; * The right to health care benefits; * The right to maternity leave; * The right to sick pay; * The right to travel provisions; * The right to vacation pay; and * The right to work injury benefits.<ref name = "Barria">Roper & Barria 2014a, p. 44</ref>
However, the following rights are not granted to migrant workers by any of the GCC countries: * The right to access to finance; * The right to anti-discrimination measures; * The right to facilitation of remittance transfers; * The right to family allowance or similar allowances; * The right to health care benefits for families; * The right to insolvency funds; * The right to pension benefits; * The right to portability provisions; * The right to pre-departure information and training; * The right to provisions in case of bankruptcy; * The right to wage equality; and * The right to work specific labor market integration.<ref name = "Barria"/>
==Human rights issues== Multiple human rights organizations, in particular [[Human Rights Watch]], have reported on widespread violations of labor and human rights of migrant workers in the Gulf region. Reported abuses include the confiscation of passports, mobility restrictions, excessive working hours, delayed or absent salary payments, sub par working and living conditions, as well as sexual, physical and psychological abuse of workers by their employers.<ref name="Kakande2016" >Kakande, Y., "Where Are Our Passports?", ''Migrant-Rights.Org'', 5 January 2016, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2016/01/where-are-our-passports/ here]</ref><ref> Migrant-Rights.Org, "Making Visible the Experiences of Migrant Domestic Workers in Saudi Arabia", 3 October 2014, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2014/10/making-visible-the-experiences-of-migrant-domestic-workers-in-saudi-arabia/ here]</ref><ref>Gardner & Pessoa 2013, pp. 10-11</ref><ref> Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain, "Slaving Away: Migrant Labor Exploitation and Human Trafficking in the Gulf", April 2014, available [http://adhrb.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/ADHRB_Slaving-Away-Migrant-Rights-and-Human-Trafficking-the-the-Gulf-Web-Pre-Publication.pdf here]</ref><ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref> Human Rights Watch, "Kuwait: Events of 2015", 27 January 2016, available [https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2016/country-chapters/Kuwait here]</ref><ref> RT, "Deceived migrant workers in UAE forced to work as slaves – report", 26 July 2016, available [https://www.rt.com/news/353432-uae-migrant-workers-slavery/ here]</ref><ref name="HRW UAE2014" />
===Kafala system=== The kafala system has been pointed out by human rights organization as one of the main sources of some of the human rights abuses reported in the GCC countries.<ref name="HRW Kuwait2017" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Dreams" /><ref name="HRW UAE2014"/> As this sponsorship system, often enshrined in labor laws, assigns the employer with the sole responsibility for the migrant worker, it also provides the employer with a large amount of power leverage over their workers. In some GCC countries, employers have the ability to cancel a work permit at any time, while an employee cannot freely leave the employment without the employer's consent – in some cases, for example in Oman, not even when the contract is completed or if their sponsor submits the workers to abuses.<ref name="HRW Kuwait2017" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Dreams" /><ref name="HRW UAE2014"/> It is reported that migrant workers who do leave without their employer's consent have received punishment in some GCC countries, which can include re-entry bans, fines and deportation.<ref name="HRW Kuwait2017" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Dreams" /><ref name="HRW UAE2014"/> Often, migrant workers cannot leave their employment, as their employer has taken their passports. One report stated that in Qatar 90% of low income workers do not have their passports in possession.<ref>Gardner & Pessoa 2013, p. 9</ref>
As seen above, some states, such as Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar and the UAE,<ref name="Review" /><ref> Al Arabiya English, “Bahrain abolishes sponsorship system for foreign workers”, 19 December 2016, available [http://english.alarabiya.net/en/business/economy/2016/12/19/Bahrain-abolishes-sponsorship-system-for-foreign-workers.html here]</ref><ref name="KhanHarroff-Tavel2011"/><ref name="HRW Qatar2015" /><ref name="Amnesty Qatar2016" /><ref> AlJazeera, “UAE announces labour reforms to protect foreign workers”, 29 September 2015, available [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/09/uae-announces-labour-reforms-protect-foreign-workers-150929143336000.html here]</ref> have announced their commitment to amend the legal framework of the kafala system and to extend labor protection to migrant workers. Some of these states have made substantial changes to their labor laws to include migrant workers,<ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref name="Zahra2015" /><ref>Shah 2011, p. 341</ref><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015b" /><ref name="Amnesty Qatar2016" /><ref name="Steps" /><ref name = "Changes"/> other states have not implemented any changes to the kafala system.<ref name="HRW Kuwait2017" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Dreams" /><ref name="HRW UAE2014"/>
===Protection of migrant domestic workers=== The labor rights of migrant domestic workers are a separate category in this regard, as all of the Gulf states, at least until recently, excluded migrant domestic workers from the protection of labor laws.<ref>Human Rights Watch, “Bahrain: Abuse of Migrant Workers Despite Reforms”, 30 September 2012, available [https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/09/30/bahrain-abuse-migrant-workers-despite-reforms here]</ref><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015" /><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Mekheil2016" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /><ref name="auto">Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain, “Slaving Away: Migrant Labor Exploitation and Human Trafficking in the Gulf”, April 2014, pp. 45-46, available [http://adhrb.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/ADHRB_Slaving-Away-Migrant-Rights-and-Human-Trafficking-the-the-Gulf-Web-Pre-Publication.pdf here]</ref><ref>The Independent, “United Arab Emirates law to protect migrant workers fails to cover domestics”, 1 November 2015, available [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/united-arab-emirates-law-to-protect-migrant-workers-fails-to-cover-domestics-a6717146.html here]</ref> According to a report by Human Rights Watch, this leaves these workers vulnerable and open to all kinds of abuses, without any type redress available to them.<ref name="HRW Kuwait2017" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Dreams" /><ref name="HRW UAE2014"/> Some the abuses most regularly committed against migrant domestic workers according to NGO reports include sexual abuse, physical abuse, excessive working hours, the withholding of salaries, the absence of adequate food and living conditions and the confiscation of passports.<ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010b" /><ref>Pathirana, S., “Kuwait's abused domestic workers have 'nowhere to turn'”, BBC News, 13 October 2010, available [https://www.bbc.com/news/world-south-asia-11444167 here]</ref><ref name="auto"/><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Mekheil2016" /><ref>Amnesty International, “Foreign domestic workers in Qatar: Shocking cases of deception, forced labour, violence”, 23 April 2014, available [https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/mde22/010/2013/en// here]</ref><ref name="HRW UAE2014" />
Furthermore, while some sending states have prohibited migration of domestic workers to some of the Gulf states, NGOs have argued that such prohibitions only increase the possibility of such workers seeking illegal means to enter and work in Gulf states – which in turn increases the risks of forced labor and human trafficking.<ref name="HRW Kuwait2017" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Dreams" /><ref name="HRW UAE2014"/>
Some states, including Bahrain,<ref>International Domestic Workers Federation, “Bahrain: Passes new Labour Law to protect domestic workers”, 11 October 2012, available [http://idwfed.org/en/updates/bahrain-passes-new-labour-law-to-protect-domestic-workers here]</ref> Kuwait,<ref name="HRW Kuwait2015" /> Oman,<ref>Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain, “Spotlight on Oman: A Move to Protect Migrant Domestic Workers”, 8 May 2016, available [http://www.adhrb.org/2016/05/spotlight-oman-move-protect-migrant-domestic-workers/ here].</ref> and Qatar,<ref name = "HRW Qatar2017" /> have announced intentions to amend or have indeed amended existing labor laws to give domestic workers better legal protection.
===Payment of (minimum) wages=== Most of the Gulf states have not adopted any minimum wage requirements,<ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref>Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain, “Slaving Away: Migrant Labor Exploitation and Human Trafficking in the Gulf”, April 2014, p. 33, available [http://adhrb.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/ADHRB_Slaving-Away-Migrant-Rights-and-Human-Trafficking-the-the-Gulf-Web-Pre-Publication.pdf here]</ref><ref>Rejimon, K., “'Expat workers should get minimum wage in Oman’”, Times of Oman, 16 June 2015, available [http://timesofoman.com/article/58493/Oman/Call-for-expat-workers-in-Oman-to-get-a-guaranteed-minimum-wage-under-revised-labour-laws here]</ref><ref>Khoja, S., “Employment & labour law in Saudi Arabia”, Lexology, 20 June 2016, available [http://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=6ba28ace-2bcf-49a7-9cba-98b08a8ff5a6 here]</ref><ref>Export.gov, “UAE – Labor”, 8 November 2016, available [https://www.export.gov/article?id=United-Arab-Emirates-labor here]</ref> and migrant workers often fall within the category of “low pay” labor. In 2012, Human Rights Watch reported that Bahraini migrant workers comprised 98% of the “low pay” labor group and most of the migrant workers interviewed by Human Rights Watch earned between BD40 and BD100 ($106 and $265) as their monthly salary.<ref name = "Steps"/><ref name="HRW Qatar2015"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015"/><ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010"/> However, in 2016 Kuwait became the first Gulf state to set a minimum wage for domestic work and is set at KD60 (approximately $200) per month.<ref>AlJazeera, “Kuwait sets minimum wage for domestic workers”, 14 July 2016, available [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/kuwait-sets-minimum-wage-domestic-workers-160714143830769.html here]</ref><ref name="KuwaitWage 2016" >Migrant-Rights.Org, “Kuwait Sets Minimum Wage for Domestic Workers”, 16 July 2016, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2016/07/13795/ here]</ref>
Another issue concerns delayed or absent salary payments.<ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref>Migrant-Rights.Org, “Kuwaiti Migrants Endure Delayed Wages & Government Apathy”, 7 February 2014, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2014/02/kuwaiti-migrants-endure-delayed-wages-government-apathy/ here]</ref><ref name="MigrantsOIlCompany Oman2015" >Migrant-Rights.Org, “Oil Companies Leave Migrants Stranded in Oman Without Pay”, 27 August 2015, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2015/08/oil-companies-leaves-migrants-stranded-in-oman-without-pay/ here]</ref><ref>Gardner, A., Pessoa, S. and Harkness, L., “Labour Migrants and Access to Justice in Contemporary Qatar”, ''Middle East Center'', November 2014, p. 15, available [http://www.lse.ac.uk/middleEastCentre/publications/Reports/LabourMigrantsQatarEnglish.pdf here]</ref><ref>Hatoum, L. and Alelyan, A., “A Crisis At Hand”, ''Newsweek Middle East'', 10 August 2016, available [http://newsweekme.com/a-crisis-at-hand/ here]</ref><ref>RT, “Deceived migrant workers in UAE forced to work as slaves – report”, 26 July 2016, available [https://www.rt.com/news/353432-uae-migrant-workers-slavery/ here]</ref> For example, in Oman it was reported that falling oil prices and the nationalization program not only led to a drop in new projects in the oil sector, but also to stranded migrant workers who often had not been paid for six months, who did not have employment and whose work permits had expired in the meantime.<ref name="MigrantsOIlCompany Oman2015" /><ref>Rejimon, K., “Send Stranded Expat Workers Home, Says Oman’s Ministry of Manpower Official”, ''Times of Oman'', 25 September 2016, available [http://timesofoman.com/article/92931/Oman/Government/Send-stranded-expat-workers-home-says-Oman's-Ministry-of-Manpower-official here]</ref> Some of these workers went on to find new employment, and without the permission of their previous employer, lost their work permit and thus became undocumented.<ref name="MigrantsOIlCompany Oman2015" /> Both the delayed and absent salary payments were found to be the greatest violations of labor laws during inspections in Oman in 2013.<ref>Migrant-Rights.Org, “Migrants in Oman Lodges 2,279 Complaints in the First Quarter of 2013”, 21 November 2013, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2013/11/migrants-in-oman-lodges-2279-complaints-in-the-first-quarter-of-2013/https://www.migrant-rights.org/2013/11/migrants-in-oman-lodges-2279-complaints-in-the-first-quarter-of-2013/ here]</ref>
Another issue with the payment of salaries, as reported by Migrant-Rights.Org, relates to the creation of so-called Wage Protection Systems in the Gulf states.<ref name = "Earning">Migrant-Rights.Org, “Oman Announces a New Wage Database… To Make Sure Workers Aren’t Earning Too Much”, 23 January 2017, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2017/01/oman-announces-a-new-wage-database-to-make-sure-workers-arent-earning-too-much/ here]</ref> While the Gulf's governments claim the aim of the system is to protect labor rights, according to Migrant-Rights.Org the Omani government has recently stated that it intends to use the system to monitor and gather information about the wages and bank accounts of workers – in order to keep an eye on remittances sent back to the home country.<ref name = "Earning"/> According to the same Migrant-Rights.Org report, the Omani government regards remittances as “wasted investment” and wishes to offer its economy better protection against such losses.<ref name = "Earning"/> The government of Saudi Arabia is also reported to use the Wage Protection System to control the finances and spending of migrant workers.<ref name = "MigrantRightsSaudiArabia2016"/> Furthermore, while there have not been any specific proposals in this regard, the [[International Monetary Fund]] has warned against potential plans of Gulf states to implement of remittance taxes to increase state revenue.<ref>Maceda, C., “IMF cautions vs tax on expat remittances, personal incomes”, ''Gulf News'', 29 November 2016, available [http://gulfnews.com/business/economy/imf-cautions-vs-tax-on-expat-remittances-personal-incomes-1.1936961 here]</ref>
===Deportations=== In recent years, Gulf states have implemented policies of large-scale deportations of both undocumented and documented migrant workers, for a variety of reasons. According to Kuwaiti media, 14,400 migrants were deported from Kuwait between January and April 2016.<ref name="HRW Kuwait2017" /> In 2016, a total of 29,000 migrants were deported from Kuwait, in comparison to about 25,000 migrants in 2015.<ref name = "Parliament">Migrant-Rights.Org, “Kuwait Deported 29,000 Migrants in 2016 – And the Parliament Wants to Deport More”, 15 January 2017, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2017/01/kuwait-deports-29000-migrants-in-2016-and-the-parliament-wants-to-deport-more/ here]</ref> In 2013, almost a million migrants were deported from Saudi Arabia, according to Migrant-Rights.Org, in order to boost employment of Saudi nationals and protect national security.<ref name="GCCStrikes2014" >Migrant-Rights.Org, “Labor Strikes in the GCC: Deportations and Victories in 2014”, 29 October 2014, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2014/10/labor-strikes-in-the-gcc-deportations-and-victories-in-2014/ here]</ref> In the same year, 7,346 undocumented migrants were deported from Bahrain.<ref>Migrant-Rights.Org, “7,346 Deported from Bahrain in 2013”, 3 January 2014, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2014/01/7346-deported-from-bahrain-in-2013/ here]</ref> In 2016 reportedly more than 600 migrants were deported from Oman in just seven day.<ref>Times of Oman, “640 expatriates arrested, 409 deported for violating labour law in Oman”, 7 December 2016, available [http://timesofoman.com/article/98083/Oman/Government/640-expatriates-arrested-409-deported-for-violating-labour-law-in-Oman here]</ref>
Migrant workers are reportedly often deported for minor transgressions, such as traffic violations, barbecuing in public spaces, complaints about working conditions, organizing strikes or violations of the terms of the residency and work permits.<ref name="GCCStrikes2014" /><ref name="MigrantsKuwaitPrison2016" >Migrant-Rights.Org, “Detention of Migrant Workers at Kuwait’s Central Prison”, 12 January 2016, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2016/01/detention-of-migrant-workers-at-kuwaits-central-prison/ here]</ref><ref>MEE, “More than 100 migrant workers may be deported after Qatar strike”, 26 November 2014, available [http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/over-100-migrant-workers-threatened-deportation-after-three-day-strike-qatar-2081152951 here]</ref><ref>Batty, D., “Migrants building UAE cultural hub 'risk abuse if they complain'”, The Guardian, 10 February 2015, available [https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/feb/10/migrants-united-arab-emirates-human-rights-watch here]</ref> The arrested migrants often only spend three days to a week in prison before the actual deportation, leaving them without time or means to appeal the deportation decision.<ref name = "Parliament"/> Nevertheless, these mass deportations still lead to overcrowded prisons, human rights organizations have reported.<ref>Migrant-Rights.Org, “Kuwait’s Police Stations “Crammed” With Deportees”, 3 June 2014, available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2014/06/kuwaits-police-stations-crammed-with-deportees/ here]</ref> It is argued that these mass deportations are part of the Gulf States’ policies to increase employment of their nationals and to improve national security.<ref name="MigrantsKuwaitPrison2016" />
In spring 2013, King [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia]] announced a government policy focused on deportation of irregular migrants, which required these migrants to regularize their status or to leave.<ref name = "Slaving">Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain, “Slaving Away: Migrant Labor Exploitation and Human Trafficking in the Gulf”, April 2014, pp. 47-48, available [http://adhrb.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/ADHRB_Slaving-Away-Migrant-Rights-and-Human-Trafficking-the-the-Gulf-Web-Pre-Publication.pdf here]</ref> While about one million foreign workers left voluntarily, reports estimate that between November 2013 and March 2014 around 370,000 migrant workers were forcibly deported from Saudi Arabia.<ref name = "Slaving"/> It was reported that crimes were committed by the Saudi police against these migrants, including extreme violence, torture, rape and killing.<ref name = "Slaving"/>
===Access to legal remedies=== Although access to legal remedies is provided by the 1990 [[International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of Their Families]],<ref>United Nations Human Rights: Office of the High Commissioner, International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of their Families, 1990 (GA Res. 45/158), art. 83.</ref> and the [[Migrant Workers (Supplementary Provisions) Convention, 1975|1975 Migrant Workers Convention (Supplementary Provisions)]],<ref>International Labour Organization, Migrant Workers (Supplementary Provisions) Convention, 1975 (No. 143), art. 9(2).</ref> these conventions have not been ratified by the Gulf states.<ref>United Nations Human Rights: Office of the High Commissioner, "Status of Ratification: International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of their Families", last accessed 20 February 2017, ''available [http://indicators.ohchr.org/ here'']</ref><ref>International Labour Organization, "Ratifications of C143 - Migrant Workers (Supplementary Provisions) Convention, 1975 (No. 143)", last accessed 20 February 2017, ''available [http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312288 here'']</ref> Nevertheless, access to legal redress for labor rights violations is provided in some Gulf states,<ref>Sultanate of Oman, Ministry of Manpower, ''Labour Law, issued by Royal Decree No. 35/2003'', art. 104, available [https://www.manpower.gov.om/Portal/Englishpdf/Service/toc_en.pdf here]</ref><ref>Gardner, A., Pessoa, S. and Harkness, L., “Labour Migrants and Access to Justice in Contemporary Qatar”, ''Middle East Center'', November 2014, p. 22, available [http://www.lse.ac.uk/middleEastCentre/publications/Reports/LabourMigrantsQatarEnglish.pdf here]</ref><ref>Human Rights Watch, “Bad Dreams: Exploitation and Abuse of Migrant Workers in Saudi Arabia”, 15 July 2004, available [https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/saudi0704.pdf here]</ref> the accessibility of these remedies in practice is often hampered by multiple factors.
One set of issues relates to language and mobility barriers, which hinder migrant workers’ access to institutions, information and services. Many migrant workers do not speak enough Arabic to understand the information needed to receive redress, while the lack of public transportation and the long working hours impede the mobility of migrant workers.<ref name="Mekheil2016" /> In this regard, the reportedly existing perception that the courts will favour nationals over the migrant workers does not improve the accessibility of remedies.<ref>Ahmad, A., “Migrant Workers in Kuwait: The Role of State Institutions”, ''Middle East Institute'', 2 February 2010, available [http://www.mei.edu/content/migrant-workers-kuwait-role-state-institutions here].</ref>
Another issue in this regard is the backlog of some of the Gulf countries’ courts. In the UAE, for example, Dubai courts could not keep up with the number of labor complaints filed – especially around 2008, when the global financial crisis inhibited companies from providing their employees with work or salaries.<ref name="Youha" /> Some critics have also pointed to understaffing and underfunding and the absence of coordination between enforcement agencies.<ref name="Youha" />
However, even if migrant workers gain access to legal remedies, they do not always receive redress. In the case of Bahrain, 50 Pakistani workers were detained by the authorities after they filed a complaint with the Bahraini courts concerning a lack of salary payments.<ref name = "Pakistanis">Bahrain Center for Human Rights, “50 Pakistanis detained in Bahrain for salary payment issue”, 18 January 2017, available [http://www.bahrainrights.org/en/node/8452 here]</ref> Even though the court ruled in the workers’ favour, they were still detained by the authorities for at least a year and were still imprisoned in January 2017.<ref name = "Pakistanis"/>
===The FIFA World Cup in Qatar===
Since Qatar was elected to host the [[2022 FIFA World Cup]], the country has been heavily criticized for the treatment of migrant workers in the preparations for the tournament. While Qatar has received less criticism in the past for its treatment of migrant workers than other GCC countries, the preparations for the World Cup have drawn more attention to the situation of workers' rights in the country.<ref>Human Rights Watch, "World Report 2015: Qatar", "Human Rights Watch", 2015, available, [https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2015/country-chapters/qatar here]</ref> Workers have died at a rate of one death per day, and workers' salaries are being withheld by employers.<ref>Gibson, O. and Pattisson, P., "Death toll among Qatar’s 2022 World Cup workers revealed", ''The Guardian'', 23 December 2014, available [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/23/qatar-nepal-workers-world-cup-2022-death-toll-doha here]</ref><ref name="Pattisson2013">Pattisson, P. "Revealed: Qatar's World Cup 'slaves'", "The Guardian", 25 September 2013, available [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/25/revealed-qatars-world-cup-slaves here]</ref> There are also stories of Nepalese migrant workers, constituting the single largest migrant group in Qatar, seeking refuge in the Embassy of Nepal in [[Doha]]. [[The Guardian]] stated that most Nepalese migrant workers have large debts, as they borrowed money to pay their recruitment agents.<ref name="Pattisson2013" />
Amnesty International argues that labor migration to Qatar will continue to increase, due to the World Cup constructions and labels the conditions for workers as "grim".<ref name=":4" /> An additional pull factor is the intention of the Qatari government, in light of the World Cup, to transform Doha into an international hub. Government bodies in Qatar have dismissed critiques regarding the exploitation of migrants and have referred to the exploitation of migrant workers as isolated incidents.<ref name=":4">Amnesty International, "The Dark Side of Migration", 17 November 2013, p. 5-6, available [https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/MDE22/010/2013/en/ here]</ref>
==International, regional and local responses== Multiple initiatives have been undertaken on the local, regional and international level, by both non-governmental organizations as well as governmental organizations. Responses from international organizations, civil society organizations, trade unions concerning the protection of migrant workers have increased, as have initiatives to report migrant workers' rights violations.
On the international level, several large NGOs, including [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Amnesty International]], have frequently reported on different issues regarding migrant workers' rights. Human Rights Watch has reported, ''inter alia'', on different foreign workers' rights abuses,<ref name="HRW Kuwait2017" /><ref name="HRW Qatar2017" /><ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="Dreams" /><ref name="HRW UAE2014"/> on specific vulnerable categories of migrant workers,<ref name="HRW Oman2016" /><ref name="HRW2016" /><ref name="HRW KSA2010" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010b" /><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015b" /> and on new policies and legislation implemented by the Gulf states aimed at protecting migrant workers.<ref name = "Steps"/><ref name="HRW Qatar2015"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2015"/><ref name="HRW Bahrain"/><ref name="HRW Kuwait2010"/> Amnesty International has produced similar reports,<ref>Amnesty International, "Amnesty International Annual Report 2016/17", 22 February 2017, ''available [https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/pol10/4800/2017/en/ here]''</ref><ref> Amnesty International, "India: Exploited dreams: Dispatches from Indian migrant workers in Saudi Arabia", 4 July 2014, ''available [https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/ASA20/025/2014/en/ here]''</ref><ref> Amnesty International, "Kuwait must reject proposed homophobic ‘medical tests’ on migrant workers", 11 October 2013, ''available [https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2013/10/kuwait-must-reject-proposed-homophobic-medical-tests-migrant-workers/ here]''</ref><ref> Amnesty International, "Gulf Cooperation Council: Protect Domestic Migrant Workers from Abuse", 1 May 2007, ''available [https://www.amnesty.org/fr/documents/mde04/001/2007/en/ here]''</ref> recently focusing strongly on the [[2022 FIFA World Cup]] in Qatar.<ref>Amnesty International, "Ruggie Report: Migrant workers in Qatar cannot afford more broken promises from FIFA", 14 April 2016, ''available [https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/04/migrant-workers-in-qatar-cannot-afford-more-broken-promises-from-fifa/ here]''</ref><ref>Amnesty International, "Qatar: World Cup 2022 Forced Labour", 31 March 2016, ''available [https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/campaigns/2016/03/qatar-world-cup-2022-forced-labour/ here]''</ref><ref>Amnesty International, "Qatar: Abuse of World Cup workers Exposed", 31 March 2016, ''available [https://www.amnesty.org/en/press-releases/2016/03/abuse-of-world-cup-workers-exposed/ here]''</ref><ref>Amnesty International, "Five years of human rights failure shames FIFA and Qatar", 1 December 2015, ''available [https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2015/12/five-years-of-human-rights-failure-shames-fifa-and-qatar/ here].''</ref> The International Organisation for Migration has also published reports on migrant workers, covering both the Asian sending states and Gulf receiving states.<ref>McCormack, S. and Larsen, J. J., "The Other Migrant Crisis - Protecting Migrant Workers against Exploitation in the Middle East and North Africa", ''IOM'', 2015, ''available [https://publications.iom.int/system/files/pdf/other_migrant_crisis.pdf here]''</ref><ref>Crocetti, G., "Protecting the Interests of Asian Migrant Workers through Labour Market Research", ''IOM'', 6 March 2016, ''available [https://www.iom.int/news/protecting-interests-asian-migrant-workers-through-labour-market-research here]''</ref><ref> Mackenzie, C. (ed.), "Labour Migration in Asia: Protection of Migrant Workers, Support Services and Enhancing Development Benefits", ''IOM'', 2005, ''available [https://publications.iom.int/system/files/pdf/labour_migration_asia_2.pdf here]''.</ref> Although the United Nations has produced independent reports on some issues with migrant workers' rights in the Gulf,<ref>UNGA Human Rights Council, "Report of the Special Rapporteur on the human rights of migrants, Addendum: Mission to Qatar", 23 April 2014, ''available [http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Issues/SRMigrants/A-HRC-26-35-Add1_en.pdf here]''</ref><ref> UN News Centre, "Migrant workers in the Middle East often exploited, UN reports at human trafficking conference", 9 April 2013, ''available [https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=44604#.WMnJqBBXDBI here]''</ref><ref> UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs, "International Migration in the Arab Region", 11 May 2006, ''available [https://www.un.org/esa/population/meetings/EGM_Ittmig_Arab/P14_PopDiv.pdf here]''</ref><ref> Shah, N. M., "Restrictive Labour Immigration Policies in the Oil-Rich Gulf: Effectiveness and Implications for Sending Asian Countries", UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs, 5 May 2006, ''available [https://www.un.org/esa/population/migration/turin/Symposium_Turin_files/P03_Shah.pdf here]''.</ref> the International Labour Organisation is the main agency focused on the position migrant workers. One of their projects, introduced in 2016, is the Regional Fair Migration Project in the Middle East, to promote national policies which are fair to migrants, to assist states with the implementation of migrant-friendly legislation and to improve the working conditions of migrant workers.<ref>ILO, "Regional Fair Migration Project in the Middle East (FAIRWAY)", last accessed 16 March 2017, ''available [http://www.ilo.org/beirut/projects/fairway/lang--en/index.htm here]''.</ref> Additionally, they publish reports on the status of migrant workers,<ref>ILO, "Protecting the rights of migrant domestic workers, 16 July 2015, ''available [http://www.ilo.org/beirut/information-resources/factsheets/WCMS_402364/lang--en/index.htm here]''.</ref> receive complaints concerning human rights violations,<ref>ILO, "Complaint concerning non-observance by Qatar of the Forced Labour Convention", GB.326/INS/8(Rev.), 17 March 2016, ''available [http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_norm/---relconf/documents/meetingdocument/wcms_459148.pdf here]''</ref><ref> ILO, "Decision on the 14th item on the agenda: Reports of the Officers of the Governing Body Fifth report: Representation alleging non-observance by the United Arab Emirates of the Forced Labour Convention, 1930 (No. 29)", GB.322/INS/14/5, 3 November 2014, ''available [http://www.ilo.org/gb/decisions/GB322-decision/WCMS_319667/lang--en/index.htm here]''.</ref> and in 2015, the ILO also published a paper to improve and increase cooperation between Asian sending countries and the receiving Gulf countries.<ref>ILO, "Issue Paper: Promoting international cooperation and partnerships in addressing labour migration between Asia and the Gulf Cooperation Council countries", 18 August 2015, ''available [http://www.ilo.org/asia/whatwedo/publications/WCMS_393769/lang--en/index.htm here]''</ref> In December 2016, the Regional Office for Arab States of the ILO, together with the Executive Bureau of the Council of Ministers of Labour and Social Affairs of the GCC, signed a Plan of Joint Activities which focuses on several labor-related subjects, including the management of foreign labourers' issues.<ref>ILO, "ILO and GCC Council of Ministers of Labour sign a Plan of Joint Activities", 8 December 2016, ''available [http://www.ilo.org/beirut/media-centre/news/WCMS_537381/lang--en/index.htm here]''</ref>
One important NGO working on the regional level is Migrant-Rights.org <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.migrant-rights.org/about/|title=About|first=Migrant|last=Rights|date=|website=www.migrant-rights.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref>, an organisation created in 2007 which draws attention to abuses of migrant workers in the Gulf region, works together with governments to effect legislative and policy changes, informs migrants workers and gives them a voice. The organisation publishes regular reports on migrant workers' rights violations,<ref name="Review" /><ref name="Kakande2016" /><ref name="MigrantsOIlCompany Oman2015" /><ref>Migrant-Rights.Org, "Making Visible the Experiences of Migrant Domestic Workers in Saudi Arabia", 3 October 2014, ''available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2014/10/making-visible-the-experiences-of-migrant-domestic-workers-in-saudi-arabia/ here]''</ref><ref>Migrant-Rights.Org, “Kuwaiti Migrants Endure Delayed Wages & Government Apathy”, 7 February 2014, ''available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2014/02/kuwaiti-migrants-endure-delayed-wages-government-apathy/ here].''</ref> on legislative changes within the Gulf states,<ref name="Earning" /><ref name="FlexibleWork Bahrain2016" /><ref name = "Unified"/><ref name = "MigrantRightsSaudiArabia2016"/><ref name="KuwaitWage 2016"/><ref name="BahrainScrapped" /> and on personal stories from migrant workers.<ref>Saraswati, V., "[Stories of Origin] In Sri Lanka, men are free, women have a price tag", Migrant-Rights,org, 14 February 2017, ''available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2017/02/stories-of-origin-in-sri-lanka-men-are-free-women-have-a-price-tag/ here]''</ref><ref>Saraswati, V., "[Stories of Origin] Dreams… perpetually in progress", Migrant-Rights,org, 14 February 2017, ''available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2017/02/stories-of-origin-dreams-perpetually-in-progress/ here]''</ref><ref>Migrant-Rights.org, "“When I got to the house, I realized that it was slavery”", 16 November 2016, ''available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/2016/11/when-i-got-to-the-house-i-realized-that-it-was-slavery/ here]''</ref> They also provide detailed information, numbers and infographics.<ref>Migrant-Rights.org, "Infographics: Visualising exploitation", last accessed 16 March, ''available [https://www.migrant-rights.org/infographics/ here]''</ref> Additionally, they published a graph <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.migrant-rights.org/our-networks/|title=Our Networks|first=Migrant|last=Rights|date=|website=www.migrant-rights.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref> including all the different organisations and civil society groups they are connected with, including organizations for the general protection of migrant workers and location-specific organizations. Another organisation is the Migrant Forum Asia <ref>{{cite web|url=http://mfasia.org/about-us/the-organization/|title=The Organization - Migrant Forum in Asia|author=|date=|website=mfasia.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref>, a regional network of NGOs, trade unions, associations and individuals created for the protection of migrant workers' rights and the promotion of their wellbeing. They have reported on multiple issues involving Asian migrant workers in the Gulf region.<ref>MFA, "Call for immediate intervention on the massive arrests of undocumented Indian migrant workers in Oman", 8 December 2016, ''available [http://mfasia.org/call-for-immediate-intervention-on-the-massive-arrests-of-undocumented-indian-migrant-workers-in-oman-2/ here]''</ref><ref>MFA, "Jennifer Dalquez – Migrant Worker Sentenced to Death by U.A.E Court", 11 March 2017, ''available [http://mfasia.org/jennifer-dalquez-migrant-worker-sentenced-to-death-by-u-a-e-court/ here]''</ref>
One example of a national organisation is Lawyers for Human Rights International <ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.lfhri.org/ | title=LFHRI}}</ref>, an India-based NGO which campaigns for the protection of Indian migrant workers overseas. One of the main objectives of the NGO is to raise awareness about human rights abuses taking place in the GCC.<ref name="Youha" /> Furthermore, in 2003 the UAE chapter of the Migrante International was created, an alliance of Filipino migrant worker organizations across the world.<ref name="Youha" /> The objectives of the organisation are mainly to strengthen labor protection, and to increase penalties for recruitment agencies which violate Filipino laws and for employers who violate UAE labor laws.<ref name="Youha" /> The organisation additionally provides services such as training, legal advice, counseling and temporary shelter for Filipinos who experience abuse from their employers.<ref name="Youha" /> Two other organisations active in Bahrain are the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bahrainrights.org/issue/term/16|title=Migrant workers - Bahrain Center for Human Rights|author=|date=|website=www.bahrainrights.org|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref> , focusing on migrant workers' rights amongst other issues, and the Migrant Workers Protection Society<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mwpsbahrain.com/|title=MWPS - The Migrant Workers Protection Society|author=|date=|website=www.mwpsbahrain.com|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref> , created in 2005 to assist migrant workers in receiving full human rights protection. An example of an individual initiative is the development of a smartphone app for migrant workers, created by an Indian journalist in Oman in 2016 together with the Migrant Forum Asia.<ref name=":0">Singh, T., "Indian Workers Facing Trouble in Gulf Countries Can Instantly Get Help with This App", ''The Better India'', 26 February 2016, ''available [http://www.thebetterindia.com/46901/migcall-app-for-migrant-workers-in-gulf-countries/ here]''</ref> On downloading, the app, called MigCall, saves ten helpline telephone numbers which provides access to services in six different languages.<ref name=":0" /> During registration, the user must also supply an emergency contact number. In case of an emergency, the user can press the SOS button in the app and a message will be sent to the emergency contact, while the user's GPS location will be sent to the closest Indian embassy or consulate.<ref name=":0" /> In February 2016, the app had been downloaded 12.000.000 times.<ref name=":0" />
Because of the activities of these NGOs, international organisations and local initiatives, large proportions of available data concerning migrant workers and their working conditions come from organisations.<ref name="Sonmez">{{cite journal |last1=Sönmez |first1=Sevil |last2=Apostolopoulos |first2=Yorghos |last3=Tran |first3=Diane |last4=Rentrope |first4=Shantyana |title=Human rights and health disparities for migrant workers in the UAE |journal=Health and Human Rights |date=2011 |volume=13 |issue=2 |pages=17–35 |url=https://www.hhrjournal.org/2013/08/human-rights-and-health-disparities-for-migrant-workers-in-the-uae/ |accessdate=28 November 2018 |ref=harv}}, pp. 1-19.</ref> During the past decades, these actors have investigated labor conditions, human rights violations, demographics and movements, and have further created guidelines for both recipient and sending countries in order to monitor, investigate, report and strengthen policies aimed at protecting migrant workers in the GCC.<ref name="Sonmez" />
== Impact of migrants == The GCC constitutes one of the most attractive geographical regions for migrants globally, mainly due to its economic pull factors. International migrants have further contributed to a large proportion of the [[economic growth]] in the GCC.<ref>Naufal & Termos 2010a, p. 37</ref><ref>Colton, N. a. “The International Political Economy of Gulf Migration,” Middle East Institute Viewpoints, 2010 p. 34, available [http://www.voltairenet.org/IMG/pdf/Migration_and_the_Gulf.pdf here]</ref> The national populace did generally not have the numbers or [[know-how]] to implement the development objectives set by the respective national leaderships of the GCC countries. Development plans outlined by several political leaders in the GCC were therefore in need of a high amount of labor migrants. These labor migrants are mainly linked to the [[private sector]], where salaries are lower and hours longer. On the other hand, national citizens in the GCC mainly work in the government-sponsored [[public sector]] where labor conditions are generally better.<ref name = "Colton">Colton, N. A. “The International Political Economy of Gulf Migration”, ''Middle East Institute Viewpoints'', February 2010, p. 34-36, available [http://www.voltairenet.org/IMG/pdf/Migration_and_the_Gulf.pdf here]</ref>
After the [[first Gulf War]] in 1990-1991, Kuwait was especially affected. The immense deprivation of the country required Kuwait to rebuild the country's economy and infrastructure, mainly through the reconstruction of the [[petroleum industry]]. Although the pre-war level of the GDP per capita was achieved already in 1992, it constituted a costly the process.<ref>Shehabi, M., R., "An extraordinary Recovery: Kuwait Following the Gulf War," Business School University of Western Australia, 2015, p. 1-28, available [http://www.business.uwa.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/2765850/15.20-Shehabi,-M.-An-Extraordinary-Recovery-Kuwait-Following-the-Gulf-War.pdf here]</ref> The outcome was that a large number of Kuwaitis started to push for [[workforce nationalization]] through “Kuwaitization” of the labor force in the country, as it was argued that migrants took work opportunities away from the national citizens. According to Nora Ann Colton, a Professor of [[International Economics]] at [[Drew University]], the "Kuwaitization" movement was a product of poor planning by the authorities in charge and could have been avoided. However, Kuwaiti authorities enforced policies which required nationals to have a lower skill set than non-Kuwaitis. Similar policies were spread throughout the GCC-region during a relatively short time period. There still exists the concern today that national unemployment will increase, and therefore authorities work to integrate nationals within the private sector. The verdict so far is that these initiatives have proven to be largely unsuccessful.<ref name = "Colton"/>
== See also == * [[Migrant worker]] * [[Kafala system]] * [[Migrant domestic workers]] * [[Migrant domestic workers in Lebanon]] * [[Remittance]] * [[Migrant Workers (Supplementary Provisions) Convention, 1975]] * [[United Nations Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of Their Families]]

Decree No. 201 | first_award = June 7, 1992 | last_award = | total = | posthumous = | recipients = | precedence_label = | individual = | higher = None | same = | lower = | related = | image2 = | caption2 = }} The '''National Hero of Azerbaijan''' ({{lang-az|Azərbaycan milli qəhrəmanı}}) is the highest [[Hero (title)|national title]] in the [[Republic of Azerbaijan]]. The title was named the highest national award on March 25, 1992, and the [["Qizil Ulduz" Medal]] awarded as a sign of receiving this title was established by a separate law in July 1992[http://azerbaijans.com/content_418_en.html On the title of "National Hero of Azerbaijan"] The law on the title has been in effect since December 25, 1995. It can be awarded only once to the same person.[http://www.mia.gov.az/qulievmadat_en.html Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Azerbaijan]. Retrieved May 29, 2007 - DEAD LINK The title is awarded for outstanding services of national importance to Azerbaijan in defense and strengthening of the state system and creation of important national values.[http://e-qanun.az/print.php?internal=view&target=1&docid=7454&doctype=0 ''""Azərbaycanın Milli Qəhrəmanı" adının təsis olunması haqqında" Azərbaycan Respublikasının Qanununda dəyişikliklər edilməsi barədə"'' Azərbaycan Respublikasının 15 iyul 1992-ci il tarixli, 210 nömrəli '''Qanunu'''] {{az}} ==Independent Azerbaijan== [[File:Salatyn and Son.JPG|thumb|[[Salatyn Asgarova]] was one of the [[Azerbaijani people|Azerbaijani]] journalists killed in the Nagorno-Karabakh war.]] After the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|break-up of the Soviet Union]] in 1991, [[Azerbaijan]] and [[Armenia]] were engaged in the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]] in which several Azerbaijanis were awarded with the ''National Hero of Azerbaijan''. {{colbegin}} * [[Mubariz Ibrahimov]] Agency]]|date=2010-07-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724175835/http://en.apa.az/news.php?id=126645|archivedate=2010-07-24|df=}} * [[Maharram Seyidov]] * [[Albert Agarunov]] revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Orphan|date=May 2012}} '''''Onde Tem Bruxa Tem Fada''''' (''Where There is Witch, There is Fairy'')<ref>{{ISBN|85-16-03164-0}} / 9788516031640</ref> is an infantile [[fairy tale|tale]] written by [[:pt:Bartolomeu Campos de Queirós|Bartolomeu Campos Queirós]], published, in first edition, in 1979,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://quintaldavo.wordpress.com/2010/01/31/311/|title=Quintal da Vó|publisher=Quintaldavo|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref> by [[:pt:Editora Moderna|Editora Moderna]].
== Synthesis == The [[book]] tells the [[narrative|story]] of a [[fairy]] that has come to the world to try to understand and to bypass the difficulties that was faced by children. She is arrested and then turns again into an "idea".
== Award == The book won the [[award]] "The Better for the Child", in 1979, by the [[:pt:Fundação Nacional do Livro Infantil e Juvenil|National Foundation for the Infantile and Juvenile Book]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itaucultural.org.br/aplicexternas/enciclopedia_lit/index.cfm?fuseaction=biografias_texto&cd_verbete=5810&cd_item=36|title=Queirós, Bartolomeu Campos de (1944 - 2012)|date=4 May 2009|publisher=Enciclopédia Itaú Cultural de Literatura Brasileira|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref>
== Interpretation == :"This is [[fairy]] story, but a different story. In a [[poetic language]], the author tells the story of a fairy that returns to the nowadays world that doesn't have place for fairies anymore. The [[magician (paranormal)|magicians]] or [[wizard (fantasy)|wizards]] and [[witch]]es take part of the [[allegory]] that subtly criticizes those who don't know how to dream, who change the [[fantasy]] and pure [[desire (emotion)|desires]] for needs artificially stimulated, who only conceive a "registered, stamped, controlled" world. The [[children]] themselves, used to that, don't know how to identify their desires anymore. Although this is an elaborate criticism to [[modern world]], the text fortunately shows us a [[counterpoint]] and a real hope light - the fact that in dreams, intimately, children know that fantasy is possible and necessary and the [[incantation|enchantment]] is more important that the [[magic (illusion)|magic]]. Beyond surveying a beautiful work with [[language]], the book opens doors to fundamental discussions for who will be the [[adult]] of tomorrow.".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olivreiro.com.br/livros/1430629-onde-tem-bruxa-tem-fada|title=Onde Tem Bruxa Tem Fada|publisher=Livreiro|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref>
:"To where does the world go without [[imagination]] and fantasy? Imagine the disappointment of Mary Heaven, a fairy that comes to earth and discovers that [[consumerism]] has dominated everyone and there is no more space to dream and fantasy! A [[legend]] full of fascinating themes, making us think of conventions imposed by [[progress (history)|progress]]. Would be the sacrifice of [[love]] and liberty in change to material comfort?<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skoob.com.br/livro/14539-onde-tem-bruxa-tem-fada|title=Onde Tem Bruxa Tem Fada|publisher=Skoob|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref>
== See also == * ''[[Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory]]''
== References == {{reflist}}
== Bibliography == * [[Bartolomeu Campos de Queirós|Queirós, Bartolomeu Campos]]. ''Onde Tem Bruxa Tem Fada''. Editora Moderna, 1983
<!-- {{Translated page|pt|Onde Tem Bruxa Tem Fada|version=27759880}} -->
